Light and airy without being thin-bodied (if that makes any sense). Goes down really smooth and could even be sessionable. 

Another RR beer that doesnt disappoint.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2009 Clear golden yellow color. Aroma is fruity sweet and tart with some faint funk. A blonde but very champagne like. Nice bubbles but not overwhemlming. Balanced, some bitterness and spice. Smooth and light.

Bottle... Murky golden ale with a small, creamy, white head. Lots of small floaties tooling about my glass. The earthy, lightly acidic aroma is of pale grains, wood and straw. As with most Russian River beers, this one offers terrific balance between bitter, sweet and tangy... it sways, maybe a hair, toward bitter. Full-bodied with a coarse mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Tangy, caustic, Mojave-dry finish. Thanks, mgumby10, for providing the sample!

Batch 2. A mid-sized white head quickly fades and gives full revelation to a clouded deep yellow/light orange pour. Copious coagulated protein chunks, a la Abbaye des Rocs, clutter the glow. Spotty, irregular lacing. Aromatic complexity is as soft as it gets whilst retaining an elegance reserved for very few beers, particularly Belgian golden ales. Everyhting is subtle and restrained, but not without a streamlined and clean crispness and regal quality. Notes of superb Belgian yeast, light candi sugar, fresh grain, coriander and lemon zest in moderation, very light tangerine rind, a respectable maize component and no alcohol whatsoever comprise the bulk of the aroma. The remainder, in very small quantities, includes mint, honey and freshly picked white flowers. The nose is great, though Id prefer greater expression, at least of the yeast. It does topple the pyramid in one aspect, one that is most laudable: it is so clean its heavenly. The flavor is very refreshing. Astringency is multifarious, with a breakdown of familiar acids as such - 60% lemon, 30% honey and 10% orange. Lovely malt, very clean throughout. Candi sugar is fully and perfectly utilized and never overzealous. The finish is lightly sweet and lightly sticking, lengthy and soft, peppery yeast and fruit lingering. The palate is silky soft and light bodied. Medium carbonation results in a great, easygoing, sessionable Belgian golden ale for the ages. This is great no matter what its compared to.

Mgumby, thanks again. 	Color is to be expected for the style, cloudy and a golden color.  Aroma is subdued and elegant.  Odd, I pick up a slight leather aroma.  Crisp flavor, some slight citrus notes.  Very refreshing.

Courtesy Irishboy.  Pours a hazy orange with a sall white head.  Smells of some Belgian candy sugar, sweet malts, and maybe a touch of some spice.  Overall quite mild.  The flavor is somewhat mild like the aroma, but still quite tasty.  Not extremely complex.  Has more of a citric orange flavor mixed in with some candy sugar and sweet malts.  Just a touch of a little funk and spice, but nothing over the top.  Not mind blowing, but another nicely crafted brew from Russian River.

Batch 3 bottle. Hazy golden, moderate head, good lacing and retention. Aroma is funky, lemony, more fruit notes, some hefelike qualities. Medium to light body, very drinkable. Somewhat sweet but not overly so, light tartness. Very tasty for such a light beer.

Didnt notice a batch number. Very thin head. Not a lot of aroma but hints of spice and lemon. Medium cloudy yellow. Starts light, then a busy middle and finish. Trying to be funky and farmhouse and ends up more like a day at the beach.

Pale golden. Fluffy white maintains a fine layer of creaminess as it collapses at a relatively quick pace.  Bright notes of honeysuckle, herbs, aniseed, pineapple, and honeydew melon delight the olfactory senses, along with inklings of crackers, straw, and minerals. Very perfumey. Robust and fairly loose carbonation. Virtually weightless first sip reveals airy phenols and an acidic sparkle of honeydew and unripe peaches. Honeysuckle flavors accentuate and seemingly prolong the slick fruitiness, though the body is slightly flabby. Malts are extracted cleanly and do showcase some pleasant straw and cracker aspects, but their lack of depth fails  to match and  enhance the crunchy, palate-scrubbing phenols. Undeniably quenching, quaffable and clean. Leafy herbs sharpen their bite toward the latter half and pierce the layer of flabbiness. Bitterness is beautifully restrained, yet possesses a sharp herbal and grassy quality which is underlined by a rounded lemony tartness. Finishes dry with a brisk phenolic snap, as well as slickly fruity with lemon oil, melon and a present yet underutilized malt-derived starchiness. Lingering malts teeter on the edge of grainy. While this batch is well constructed, I prefer the deeper Pilsner maltiness of the first batch. Top-notch stuff, though. Simply stunning in all its modesty, yet staggeringly complex at the same time. This still ranks as one of the best session beers on the planet, even without the brett. Vinnie sure knows how to get the most out of his yeast.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: AUG 7, 2007 Batch 002.  A very cloudy pour, though bright and golden.  Fermenting fruit cocktail, weeds, sweat, and cow farm hay on the nose.  Pungent and warm.  A sparkle of pear and champagne taste leads.  Dandelion stems and spinach leave strange vegetal creases on a buttery malt body.  Cloves finish.  A touch of creaminess in the mouth is slightly misplaced.  Sprightly and sharp otherwise.  A bit quiet with a very understated complexity, almost kept in secret.  Thanks Keith!

Sampled at Russian River on draught in mid-June 2007. Very light clear golden with a white head. Clove, a little grass and banana in the nose. Flavor of pale/pils malt, lightly phenolic, clove, banana, hay and citrus/lemon. Medium bodied, smooth texture with fine-beaded carbonation. Well-done.

750 ml bottle. Batch 002. Pours a hazy golden orange with an intense white head. Excellent lacing. Biscuity nose with hints of clove and citrus. Smooth complex body. Initial sweetness gives way to a crisp hoppy edge with hints of banana, lemon and clove.

750ml bottle, Batch 002. Head is initially large, frothy, white, mostly lasting. Body is hazy medium yellow, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain), moderately hoppy (flowers, herbs), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of lemon/lime/orange zest, Juicy Fruit gum, clove, spearmint, pepper, honey. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation. Belgian golden ales just dont get much tastier, cleaner, or more complex than this. Yes, its got a bit less going on in the nose and less tartness than the perfect 5 that was Bretty Redemption, but whats left is still nothing short of amazing.  And here I was all prepared to give it a mid-3 score.  Sheesh.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2007 Pour is orange with a bit of red and a nice white head.  Aroma of fruity malt, hops, lemon, and spices.  Flavors of Belgian yeast, citrus, banana, lemon, and some sourness.  Very refreshing and tasty.

75 cl bottle from Ledgers. Rich aroma of malt and grassy hop at first. Almost like a very rich lager. Except there is fruit present. Orange tinged gold color. White head, which left rather rapidly. Medium mouthfeel, a bit fizzy, and there is a slick feel for a moment. It finishes with some spice and bitter. There is a lot of fruit and spice in the middle. For me the fruit is stone fruit and orange. It is really very tasty, and it could be taken for a Belgian import.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2007 From the corked and caged 500 ml bottle purchased from the brewpub this poured a cloudy yellow gold with a nice sized white head that left average lacing.  Big nose of fruit, with banana first, but also touches of apple, pears, and apricot.  Mouthfeel is rich and almost oily.  Yeasty flavor and a dry finish. Nice Belgian Ale.
25April07 on tap @ Russian River.  light golden color.  strong malt aroma.  malt flavors.  balanced hop finish.  very basic.
Beautiful golden honey color with fluffy white head.  Aroma of yeast, banana, and spices.  smooth light palate.  Taste of banana, spice, lemon sourness, and spices with a crisp dry finish.

Pours clear gold with good carbonation and a frothy white head.  Yeast esters, banana, clove, and spice fill teh nose.  Light mouthfeel compliments the taste.  Banana, lemon, breadiness up front with malt and spice in the back.  Yum.

Draught. 
Light golden body with a creamy white head. The aroma is grassy with lemony hops and sweet doughy malts. The flavour has a lot of base cereal malts with a nice fruit character and herbal hops. Finishes spritzy and relatively brash. Quite refreshing.

Sampled at the Pizza Port 12 Hour Belgian Beer Party on March 24, 2007.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2008 From a 750mL Bottle, Batch 004.  Pours a crystal clear, transparent color of brass, topped with a thick head of foamy white.  Fruity and lightly spicy fruit esters, rich with smooth apple and pear, livened by some restrained earthy pepper.  A fresh styrian goldings hop dose adds a wonderful herb garden floral character.  Medium light bodied, heavy carbonated mouthfeel with a smooth, almost creamy texture.  A pleasant, bready malt body up front on the palate, along with touches of wheat acidity.  Light and easy drinking, but wonderfully malty as well.  Classic Belgian yeast esters come out mid-palate, creating an earthy, birch bark perfume when combined with the garden fresh hops.  Moderate-light hop finish, leaving behind a delicate lingering bitterness.  Marvelous.  Thanks, Julian!


Batch 001, on draft.  Pours a light, but not pale, transparent golden color with a nice layer of tight white head.  Clean, light fruit estery aroma of crisp pinot grigio grapes, under-ripe green pears and some meyer lemon zest.  Very light, clean and dry mouthfeel with a crisp, sparkling carbonation.  Extremely refreshing, and packed with delicate flavor complexity between the light fruits, gentle white pepper spice, and bready malts.  Clean finish, with a hint of grassy hops.  Perfect beer for a hot, sunny day.

Lots and lots of full pours at PP Belgian Fest on 3/24/07I proudly proclaimed that Id give this as high a score as the bottled version, upon trying it.  But I think that was a bit of overzealousness caused by the moment and how incredibly good this stuff is.  But, I cant deny that the brett makes it a more enjoyable beer, with light tartness, more crispness and complexity and, in my mind, no drawbacks.  The brett dosent dominate the beer, nor does it take away from the generous, but well-attenuated maltiness and clean, elegant, plastery-like saccharomyces nuances.The appearance is similar to the bottled version, almost identical, of course, but for the much more controlled, smaller white head.  Still a good bit of it, with light lacing left behind on the glass and a high clarity in the blonde liquid.Ill just say that for my money, this is about as good as saccharomyces gets.  Very light, clean esters are neither overly sharp or exuberantly fruity, but yield more pear/nectarine/grapeskin-like notes.  In concert with the delicate honey notes collected from the malt, its one of the most elegant and understated aromas out there.  Soft dough/plaster and very light vanilla sit on the end, further emphasizing the yeast.  Minimal, peppery and grassy hops show only light aromatics and no bitterness, as an abbey singel should.  Tough to put in to words such an understated, reserved beer, and for most, it will just come off as "too light" or "weak".  Not in my opinion, thats for sure.Terrific balance is foremost its greatest factor in the flavor, possibly tied with drinkability.  Very slightly chewy malt adds almost a wheat-like consistency and gives light vanilla, cream and lemon notes through the middle, that give quite a bit of flavor, for the beers size.  A flavor that I can only describe as rose water, or some type of floral-infused spring water, with a touch of pearskin, hangs about as well, climaxing on the finish, along with a pinch of nuttiness and light grain.  Divinely clean with just a pinch of spicy phenolics on the end.  Light carbonation, very strong texture for its size.  Delicious and the best session beer on the market, IMHO.  A lot of craftmanship to see here, if you take your time with it (or drink 5 or 6 glasses of it).  Repeat after me, "Quality, not Quantity."

Bottle. I have to say I still cannot believe that it is only 4.8%. A much bigger tatsing beer with a great breadiness, smooth maltiness and a bit of hops. My favorite with a pizza since it has big flavors without being filling.Earlier Rating: 12/10/2005 Total Score: 3.8Tap at the Hopyard. A well constructed Belgian style ale. It appears quite clear, I would have expected a more unfiltered appearance.
Color is golden, head is medium thick and long lasting. Flavor and araoma are dominated by yeasty nuances.
Nice slighlty bitter taste on the palate with a lingering finish.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2007 Pizza Port Belgian Beer Fest. On tap. Nose of light candied Belgian phenols, yeasty and bready alike. Clear gold pour, with soap in white. Rich, spicy peppery tooth with a hint of sweet lemon, rounding full grain flavor and a satisfying light malt body over an amazing drinkability. Lemon thyme crispness curls balance in the backend. A truly satisfying beer in every sense.
Funky nose, pale gold color, fluffy sticky head. Sweet malt, yeast, citrus note. Thin body. Excellent Belgian style beer. Amazing that this was done in the USA.

Draft at PP Belgian Beer Fest.  Aromas were a little sour and a bit soapy.  Flavors were better with some earthy and spicy notes.  Pepper on the finish.  Touches of alcohol blended with the aftertaste.  Pretty good

Draft at the brewpub. Poured a clear golden color. Head was thin, white, and left only scant lace. Aroma and flavor were of subdued clove, a bit of yeasty bread dough, and light cereal grain. Very refreshing.Earlier Rating: 3/25/2007 Total Score: 3.7750 ml bottle. Poured a clear golden color. The head was white, like its brewpub counterpart, but was much bigger and left better lace. Aroma was of yeasty bread dough, flowers, and lemony citrus. Plenty of bubbles (more effervescent than the one at the brewpub). Tasty with light malty cereal grain, citrus, and fresh bread dough.
sample at pub.  This was a great belgian ale, that was drinkable but had that belgian aroma and taste to it.  Good stuff.   Why the hell didnt I take notes.

tulip at RR - Aroma is malty and yeasty with pear, bubblegum and a touch of lemon.  Pours transparent gold with a medium head and great lacing.  Flavor is bread dough, hay, lemon zest and bubblegum.  Palate is creamy and smooth.  A tasty intro into Begian goldens.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2008 Bananas, apricots and white grapes are predominate in the nose with a touch of grass, herbs and honey.  Jasmine flowers come thru on the palate. Wondefully drinkable beer with a very fruit forward finish.

tap at the brewpub - Wow, Im curious about the rating on this one.  People saw something that I missed in my sampler, I guess.  Could it be better in the bottle than on tap?  That would be odd.   Its mildly sweet and I really didnt have much to say about it as it seems like theres not a lot going on with this beer.  It smells pretty good and its refreshing as a session beer, but thats about it.  Maybe Ill be able to try it again sometime.
On tap at Russian River Brewpub: Nice golden color with a medium head. Floral - lavender nose and taste. Lemon taste. Nice one!

pint is a very bright gold with a small white head that retains well and leaves good lace.  nose has a prominent, but sudued, banana note, mixed with crackery maltiness and a lightly floral note.  lightly sweet malt flavor in the entry, with a bit of creamy fruitiness only modestly balanced by modest hop bitterness.  nice beer, easy to drink. interesting to compare to the drier and more complex bottled form.
On tap at RR in Santa Rosa. Gold with a small white head. Hoppy-fruity aroma with citrus notes. Taste is nice and hoppy with a nice bitter finish.

On tap at the brewery. Yellow gold color. Small sized white foamy head. Aroma is fruity with lots of banana and peaches. A medium bodied Belgian ale. Malts are fruity and sweet, lots of banana and peach flavors. Kind of sweet. Bright yeast, yet kind of mild tasting. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Draft. Amber color with a thin white head. Big carbonation. Aroma of yeast - some banana and clove. The aroma is great - too bad the taste doesnt quite match it. Theres some malt, some citrus (lemon), and a little yeast, but I agree below with this is half Belgian and half American. Its just not quite there.

Draught, at the brewpubGolden colour, with no particular effervescence.  Fruity aroma - apples and pears.  Light background malt.  Sweet and fruity starter beer, not really any more Belgian nor unusual than Alexander Keiths.
on tap at The Russian River Brewing Company in Santa Rosa, CA. pours cloudy amber, with a minimal egg-shell white head. lacing. piny hops and nuts. some almond. yeast. clean.

Of the six "tion" beers that Ive tried of Russian River, this is probably my least favorite.  But, then again, that is like saying, Emeralds are my least favorite gemstone.  Translation:  Theyre all pretty damn good.  You can definitely detect the quality ingredients and hard work that they put into crafting each and every beer.  This beer had some wonderful yeasty flavors complemented with warm spices and sweet malt.  Not too shabby.
UPDATED: JAN 28, 2006 (on tap at brewpub) a fruity golden.  a pretty good beer, someone one sided, but nice dried fruit flavor to it, with a nice amount of apricots.
On tap poured a hazy gold with a small white head. Nose was of sour apples. Flavor was dry, tart and bicuity.
Blonde with slight haze, pleasnt sweet aroma with spices and bananas. Hybrid between pale ale and belgian ale. Lots of hops and spices. Rather bitter notes, but good bodied. (June 2004).
On tap @the brewpub.  This is a fantastic Belgium!  Pours a pale straw color with a huge white head.  Taste is dominated by the malt sweetness with a hint of yeast.  Nice dry finish.  Outstanding!

My first belgian "single" and a treat it is. Had this on a warm summer night and wanted something not to heavy but with enough stuff going on flavor-wise to keep my palate busy. This was just right. Thanks again, Russian River!

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2014 on tap at the brewery 5/2004: light fluffy, fairy floss belgian ale, aroma of cinnamon and pear, light yeast bite, not bad.  sampled again, 9 years later thanks to skykob bringing some back from the states. not a whole lot has changed - sweet and cakey, subdued yeast character

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2006 Nice golden color with a fruity/yeasty nose. It has a very clean crisp flavor; its easy to drink. I could see having a few of these on the patio on  a hot day. 
On TAP
Honey colored brew with a nice white head. Yeasty nose. Very easy drinker. Nice malty flavor with a slight bitterness near the middle and a clean finish.

Draught @ OBriens San Diego
The beer pours translucent amber with a generous white head that spumescent in texture and the lace a satin sheet to cover the glass. Nose has a nice malt sweetness, a hint of banana or maybe its pineapple, also seemed to be a hint of yeast, fresh and clean to the olfactory senses, start is sweetly malt and the top light to moderate in its feel. Finish is hop spicy, the acidity prickly and I found it to be a good drinking beer.

This brew pours with a clear golden body topped by a thin, white head with little lacing.  The aroma is slightly sweet yet sour with a slight barnyard and a touch of spice.  The flavor is slightly bitter and spicy with a very little barnyard, some malt and a touch of sweetness.  Medium bodied, slightly tingly and a touch dry.

(Draft: OBriens in San Diego, CA) This Belgian "single" is basically like a simple Belgian golden ale; Mildly spicy with moderately bitterness that becomes more prominent in the finish; Lightly sweet with only a mild amount of maltiness; Lightly malty nose; Light golden color and slightly cloudy; The off-white head started off as an island and shrunk very quickly before my eyes until nothing was left, but all the while, always floating in the center of the glass, not the edges -- very strange
